content: The House Ethics Commission Establishment Act of 2007 may be cited as the "House Ethics Commission Establishment Act of 2007" and establishes the House Ethics Commission. The House Ethics Commission, established by the House Ethics Commission Establishment Act of 2007, consists of 12 members appointed by the leaders of the House of Representatives, with terms ranging from 2 to 6 years. The House Ethics Commission consists of 12 members appointed by House leaders for terms of 2 to 6 years. The chairman and vice chairman are selected at the first meeting, with a limit of one 2-year term each. Only former House Members are eligible for appointment, with disqualifications for lobbyists within the past 4 years. Members of the House Ethics Commission must not have been lobbyists in the 4 years before their appointment. They cannot hold elected office or government positions. Vacancies are filled as per the original appointment method. Members receive compensation based on the Executive Schedule Level III rate. A majority of members forms a quorum. The House Ethics Commission requires a majority of members for a quorum. Meetings are called by the chairman or a majority of members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission is authorized to investigate alleged violations by Members, officers, or employees of the House of Representatives, issue letters of reproval, and report findings and recommendations to the House. The Commission is authorized to investigate violations by Members, officers, or employees of the House of Representatives and report evidence of violations to authorities. It also adopts rules to protect respondents during investigations. The Commission is authorized to investigate violations by Members, officers, or employees of the House of Representatives and report evidence of violations to authorities. It also adopts rules to protect respondents during investigations. SEC. 4. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, gather evidence, and issue subpoenas as necessary for carrying out its duties under the Act. Subpoenas can only be issued by the chairman or vice chairman and served by designated individuals. Upon request, the Commission can obtain information for its investigations. The Commission, chaired by the chairman, can request information from government agencies to carry out its duties. SEC. 5. PROCEDURAL RULES. The Commission requires majority approval for reports or investigations on the official conduct of House members, officers, or employees. Investigations can only be initiated by the Commission upon receipt of a written complaint from a House member or the chairman of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Commission requires majority approval for reports or investigations on the official conduct of House members, officers, or employees. Investigations can only be initiated by the Commission upon receipt of a written complaint from a House member or the chairman of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives prohibits investigations of alleged violations of laws, rules, regulations, or standards of conduct not in effect at the time of the alleged violation. Information or testimony received, complaints, or the fact of filing a complaint shall not be publicly disclosed without authorization from the Commission. The Commission can appoint staff as needed, with the director appointed jointly by the Speaker and minority leader. The director's pay should not exceed Level III of the Executive Schedule. Upon receipt of a report by the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, the Speaker of the House of Representatives must have it printed in the Congressional Record. Within 14 days of the report being printed, any recommendations for action regarding alleged violations by Members, officers, or employees must be introduced in the House by the Speaker and minority leader. A resolution introduced by the Speaker of the House and the minority leader constitutes a question of privilege under House rules. Members can call up the resolution as a question of privilege three days after announcing their intention to do so. SEC. 8. AMENDMENTS TO THE RULES OF THE HOUSE REGARDING THE COMMITTEE ON STANDARDS OF OFFICIAL CONDUCT. House Rules Amendments: Clause 3 of rule XI of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended by striking and redesignating subparagraphs, amending paragraph (b)(1), and striking various paragraphs. Amendment to the Ethics Reform Act of 1989 by striking subsections (c) and (d) in Section 803. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be effective upon enactment, with sections 3, 4, and 8 delayed until 6 months after enactment or January 3, 2009.
